translated: Treatise on Dependent Origination
Composed by the Sage Ullenga
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Dharmagupta of the Great Sui Dynasty from South India
From one, three arise; from three, six evolve;
From six, two and two again six; from six, six also arise.
From six, there are three; these three again have three;
Three again give rise to four; four again give rise to three.
From three, one arises; that one again gives rise to seven;
All the suffering within this, the Sage says, is all-encompassing.
The twelve kinds of distinctions, well-purified, are explained as emptiness;
By the power of the factors of dependent origination, one should know the twelve dharmas.
Ignorance, karmic formations, and consciousness are called name-and-form, the six sense bases,
Contact, craving, grasping, existence, birth, aging and death.
The first, eighth, and ninth are afflictions; the second and tenth are karmic actions;
The remaining seven are all suffering, and the three subsume the twelve dharmas.
The first two are the past, and the latter two are the future time,

The remaining eight are the present, and these are called the dharmas of the three times.ğŸ”½Afflictions give rise to karma, which attracts retribution, and retribution again gives rise to afflictions,
Afflictions again give rise to karma, and also due to karma there is retribution.
Apart from afflictions, how can there be karma?
Karma is also destroyed, and there is also no retribution?
Without retribution, one is free from afflictions, and these three each cease by themselves.
The five parts are born from causes and effects, and are called afflictions and karma,
The seven parts are the effects, and the seven kinds of suffering should be contemplated.ğŸ”½In the cause, there is no effect, and in the cause there is also no cause,
In the effect, there is no cause, and in the effect there is also no effect,
The cause and effect are both empty, and the wise one is in accord with this.
In the world, there are four kinds of parts, because cause and effect are combined, there is
Afflictions, karma, and fruits combined, with desire as the sixth part.
Because it is included in the sections, there are two sections and three summaries,
With cause and effect mixed as the sections, the third and fourth sections are summarized.
Two twos, three threes, and two, with five dharmas at the time of suffering,
The doer, the womb, the realm, the arising, the turning, the birth, and the flowing.
Delusion, the arising of the fruit, the flowing of the retribution fruit as the two,
In the part of the corresponding faculties, each has three parts and two parts.
The fruit of heat and poverty, the fruit of turning out and flowing,
In the part of the corresponding other, two, one, one, and one dharma.
This has twelve kinds, with equal power, arising from itself,
No sentient beings, no life, no movement, known through wisdom.
No self, no mine, no self, no cause of self,
The four kinds of ignorance are empty, the other parts are also like this.
Cutting off the two extremes of annihilationism and eternalism, this is the middle way.
If one has already realized and accomplished, the essence of realization is the buddhas.
Having realized, in the assembly, the sage-saints speak of no-self,
In the Sutra of the City Parable, the guide has explained this meaning.
The KÄtyÄyanÄ« SÅ«tra speaks of right view and the view of emptiness,
The Bá¹›hat-JÄtaka SÅ«tra also speaks of the supreme emptiness.
Those who know the characteristics of emptiness, if they do not know dependent arising,
They also do not know that emptiness.
Then they will not be disgusted with the multitude of feelings. If there is that view of non-existence,
Then they will be confused about the meaning of dependent arising.
Free from arrogance, they know emptiness, and because they are disgusted with the multitude of feelings,
They are not confused about the union of karmic results.
It is also not the case that they do not rely on this. Emptiness relies on the existence of this,
The equipment of karmic retribution and enjoyment.
Previously, it was said that dependent arising is the afflictions, karma, and suffering,
Among the three, it is like the Dharma that is included.
In the two, seven are born, and from the seven, three are born again.
The wheel of existence turns like this.
There is no separate sentient being, only these empty dharmas,
And they themselves give rise to empty dharmas.
Dependent on conditions, karma is also produced, and dependent on conditions, retribution is also produced.
There is not a single thing that does not have conditions.
Sunlight, seeds, and vinegar, the continuity of all things does not transcend to another place.
Wisdom should contemplate those two.

The main text of the Treatise on the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination in Thirty Verses is completed. I will now explain the Treatise on the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination in Thirty Verses according to the sequence.
From one, three are produced; from three, six are transformed and produced.
Six and two, two again six; from six, six are also produced.

As for from one, three are produced, one refers to ignorance. This ignorance is called ignorance. Because one is not aware of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, it is called ignorance.

Due to the absence of wisdom, there are said to be three kinds of actions: meritorious, non-meritorious, and immovable, as well as bodily actions, verbal actions, and mental actions, etc., which arise from them.

From the three arises six: from those three kinds of actions arise the six groups of consciousness, namely eye-consciousness, ear-consciousness, nose-consciousness, tongue-consciousness, body-consciousness, and mind-consciousness.
The six and two: those six groups of consciousness give rise to two kinds, namely name-and-form.
The two and six again: name-and-form give rise to the six sense bases, namely the eye sense base, ear sense base, nose sense base, tongue sense base, body sense base, and mind sense base.
From the six also arises six: from those six sense bases arise the six contacts, namely eye contact, ear contact, nose contact, tongue contact, body contact, and mind contact.
From the six there are three, these three again have three,
The three again give rise to four, the four again give rise to three.
From the six, there are three. From those six contacts, three feelings arise, namely, pleasant feeling, painful feeling, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.
These three also have three. Still from those three feelings, three kinds of craving arise, namely, craving for desire, craving for existence, and craving for non-existence.

Three again give rise to four. From those three kinds of craving, four kinds of grasping arise, namely, grasping for desire, grasping for views, grasping for precepts and observances, and grasping for self-doctrine.
Four again give rise to three. From those four kinds of grasping, three kinds of existence arise, namely, desire existence, form existence, and formless existence.
From three, one arises. That one again gives rise to seven.
All the suffering within that, the Sage says, is all included.
From three, one arises. Still using those three kinds of existence as conditions, one kind of birth in the future arises.
As for that one giving rise to seven again, it means that from that one, there will be the seven of old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, and so forth.

As for the Sage says that all that exists within is included, within this, from ignorance as the beginning to distress as the end, the immeasurable kinds of suffering, the World-Honored One has summarized and explained them all.
The twelve kinds of distinctions are well explained as emptiness.
One should understand the twelve dharmas based on the power of the links of dependent origination.
As for the twelve kinds of distinctions are well explained as emptiness, these beginning with ignorance are each distinct and unmixed, with twelve links.
Moreover, they are all empty by nature. One should correctly see that what is explained here is only the dharma of emptiness, the dharma of self-arising emptiness.

As for one should understand the twelve dharmas based on the power of the links of dependent origination, if one understands the twelve dharmas based on the power of the links of sequential arising, one should understand them in the following way: within this, the characteristic of delusion is ignorance;
The part of the verse on action is the accumulation of future characteristics;
The part of the verse on consciousness is the next stage of rebirth;
The part of the verse on name-and-form is the combination of the body of names and the body of forms;
The part of the verse on the six sense bases is the arrangement of characteristics;
The part of the verse on contact is the gathering of eye, form, and consciousness;
The part of the verse on feeling is the experience of what is loved and not loved;
The part of the verse on craving is insatiable;
The part of the verse on grasping is grasping and holding;
The part of the verse on existence is the body of names and the body of forms;
The part of the verse on birth is the arising of the five aggregates;
The part of the verse on old age is the stage of maturity;
The part of the verse on death is the cutting off of the life faculty;
In the phrase worry, the characteristic of arrogance is worry;
In the phrase compassion, the sound of crying is compassion;
In the phrase suffering, the characteristic of burning and heating the body is suffering;
In the phrase distress, the characteristic of mental distress is distress;
In the phrase exhaustion, the characteristic of extreme fatigue is exhaustion.
Ignorance, karma, consciousness, name-and-form, the three unities of the faculties,
Knowledge, thirst, grasping, accumulation, emergence, maturity, and the end.
Among them, ignorance is the absence of wisdom.
Karma is action.
Consciousness is understanding.
Name-and-form is the general aggregation of the five aggregates.
Faculties are the sense bases.
The three unities are contact.
Knowledge is feeling.ğŸ”½Thirst is craving.ğŸ”½Grasping is clinging.
Accumulation is becoming.
Emergence is birth.
Maturity is aging.
The end is death.
Moreover, the inclusion of these various characteristics, I will explain in order.
Among them, the distinctions of karma, afflictions, and retribution:
The first and ninth are afflictions, the second and tenth are karma,
The remaining seven are all suffering, the three include the twelve dharmas.
The three afflictions are ignorance, craving, and grasping.
The two karmas are karmic formations and becoming.
The seven retributions are consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, birth, and old age and death.
These twelve dharmas are included in the three kinds.
Moreover, the distinctions of time:
The first two are in the past, the last two are in the future,
The remaining eight are in the present, these are called the dharmas of the three times.
Ignorance and karmic formations, the first two kinds, are in the past.
Birth and old age and death, the last two kinds, are in the future.
Consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, and existence are the eight kinds in the present time.
Moreover, these arise from each other in sequence.
Afflictions give rise to karma, which attracts retribution, and retribution again gives rise to afflictions,
and due to afflictions there is karma, and due to karma there is retribution.

The three kinds of afflictions, karma, and retribution are as explained above. Because of those afflictions there is karma, because of karma there is retribution, and because of retribution there are afflictions. Because of afflictions there is karma, and because of karma there is retribution.
Question:
How is it that each is extinguished due to the exhaustion of afflictions?
What is the meaning of this?
Answer:
How can there be karma without afflictions? Karma is destroyed and there is also no retribution.
Without retribution, there are no afflictions. These three each extinguish themselves.

If this mind is without the defilements of afflictions, then it does not accumulate karma. If one does not create karma, then one does not experience retribution. If one extinguishes retribution, then one also does not give rise to afflictions.
In this way, these three each extinguish themselves.
Moreover, these have the aspects of cause and effect.
The five aspects of cause give rise to the effect, which is called afflictions and karma.
The seven aspects are the effect, and the seven kinds of suffering should be contemplated.
The five kinds of causes are called afflictions and karma, which are as previously explained: ignorance, formations, craving, grasping, and becoming.

The seven kinds of effects that arise in succession are also as previously explained: the seven kinds of suffering, namely, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, birth, and old age and death.

translated: Moreover, these causes and effects are both empty.ğŸ”½In the cause, there is no effect, and in the cause, there is also no cause.
In the effect, there is no cause, and in the effect, there is also no effect.
Cause and effect are both empty, the wise one is in accord with this characteristic.
The Sanskrit original is one verse, now it is one and a half verses.
If the two kinds of cause and effect spoken of here, if the cause is empty of effect, the effect is also empty of cause;
In this way, the cause is also empty of cause, and the effect is also empty of effect.
In these four limits, one should be in accord with this characteristic.
Moreover, this has another division.
In the world, there are four kinds of divisions, because of the combination of cause and effect,
The combination of afflictions, karma, and fruits, with thoughts and desires as the six divisions.

As for in the world, there are four kinds of divisions, because of the combination of cause and effect, in the path, the five kinds of causes and seven kinds of fruits combine, and in total summary, they form four kinds, with four kinds of divisions in sequence.
Among them, ignorance and karmic formations, in the past, these two dharmas are the first division.
Consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling, in the present, are the second division.
Thirst, craving, grasping, and becoming are also in the present time, as the third part.
Birth and old age and death are in the future time, with two dharmas as the fourth part.
This is called the four kinds of parts.

As for combining the afflictions, karma, and results into six parts, the three kinds of afflictions, karma, and retribution are combined in sequence, and there are six kinds of parts in the two fundamental [parts].
Among them, what is included in ignorance is taken as the root of ignorance.
What is included in thirst and craving is taken as the root of thirst and craving.

In the root of ignorance, ignorance is the part of afflictions, and action is the part of karma, while consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling are the part of retribution.
In the root of thirst and craving, thirst and craving and grasping are the part of afflictions, while becoming is the part of karma, and birth, old age, and death are the part of retribution.
Moreover, the parts are summarized in general.
Because they are included in the two parts and three summaries,
The causes and effects are mixed as sections, with three or four sections in total.

Existence is the basis, and the two sections of arising are called the first section between existence and birth, and the second section between action and consciousness. These two are both sections of karmic results.
The third section is the mixture of causes and effects in the middle of feeling and craving.
These three sections are further divided into four general summaries.

The two kinds of ignorance and action are the first general summary, the five kinds of consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling are the second general summary, the three kinds of craving, grasping, and existence are the third general summary, and the two kinds of birth and old age and death are the fourth general summary.
This refers to the three sections and four general summaries.
Moreover, the differences in time of abiding in these dharmas.
Two twos, three threes, two, the time of suffering has five dharmas,
The doer, the womb, the realm, the arising, the turning, the birth, the flowing.
As for the two pairs of dharmas, ignorance and karmic formations are said to be two kinds, and consciousness and name-and-form are said to be two kinds.
As for the three triads, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling are said to be three kinds, and craving, grasping, and becoming are said to be three kinds.
As for the two pairs, birth and old age and death are said to be two kinds.
These five dharmas are the creator in the time of suffering, the womb, the objects, the instigation, and the birth, within which they flow. One should know them according to the enumeration.
Among them, ignorance and karmic formations are said to be the creator in the time of suffering, one should see them in this way.
Consciousness and name-and-form are said to be the womb in the time of suffering, one should see them in this way.
The six sense bases, contact, and feeling are said to be the objects in the time of suffering.
Craving, grasping, and becoming are said to be the instigation in the time of suffering.
Birth and old age and death are said to be the birth in the time of suffering.
Moreover, there are distinctions in fruits.
The fruit of confusion and instigation, the fruit of retribution and flowing, are two,
In the midst of the associated faculties and divisions, each has three and two parts.
As explained above, in the first part of the faculty of ignorance and the faculty of craving, confusion, instigation, retribution, and flowing are called the four kinds of fruits.
In the midst of the divisions of the numbers one, three, and two, they should be associated according to their sequence.

Among them, ignorance is the fruit of confusion, action is the fruit of instigation, consciousness, name-and-form, and the six sense bases are the fruit of retribution, and contact and feeling are the fruit of flowing.
There are also other remaining fruits.
The fruit of heat and poverty, the fruit of turning out and flowing,
In the midst of the associated other parts, there are two, one, one, and one dharma.
As previously explained in the second part on the roots of craving, the fruits of heat, poverty, transformation, and moisture should be matched with the corresponding numbers in this teaching.
Among them, craving and grasping are the fruits of heat, existence is the fruit of poverty, birth is the fruit of transformation, and old age and death are the fruit of moisture.
Thus, there are eight fruits.
These have twelve kinds, equally powerful, arising from their own conditions,
Without sentient beings, without life, without movement, to be known through wisdom.

Thus, ignorance is the beginning, old age and death are the end, with twelve links, equally supreme, each arising from conditions, but without sentient beings, without life, without movement, to be known through wisdom.
Among them, there are no sentient beings because they are not solid.
There is no life because there is no self.
There is no movement or action because there is no doer.
No self, no what belongs to self, no self, no cause of self,
Four kinds of ignorance are empty, the other parts are also like this.

In the absence of self, there is no knowledge, in the absence of what belongs to self, there is no knowledge, in the absence of self, there is no knowledge, in the absence of the cause of self, there is no knowledge. In this, because there is no self, the four kinds of ignorance are empty.
Just as the four kinds of ignorance are empty in sequence, in the same way, one should know that the other parts such as practice and so forth are also all empty.
Free from the two extremes of annihilation and permanence, this is the middle way,
If one has already accomplished realization, the essence of realization is the buddhas.
Existence is included in permanence, non-existence is included in annihilation. Such two extremes are the conditions for that, in that place, all existences arise and transform.
Free from these two extremes is the middle way. If ignorant non-Buddhists fall into extremes, if the enlightened buddhas and world-honored ones, then it becomes the essence of realization.
In this world, only he can accomplish it, while others do not have this meaning.
After awakening, among the assembly, the sage said there is no self.
In the Sutra of the City Parable, the guide has explained this meaning.
That is also the path in this context. After awakening, the Buddha said there is no self among the various assemblies.
It is said: Monks!
There is a self and what belongs to the self. The foolish ordinary beings of the class without learning fall into conceptual designations.
In this, there is no further self or what belongs to the self.
Monks!
When arising, there is only the arising of suffering. When ceasing, there is only the cessation of suffering.
As explained by the guide in the Sutra of the City Parable, this meaning has already been spoken.
Moreover:
The Kaccana Sutta speaks of right view and the view of emptiness.
The Bhara Sutta (on the constellation Bharani) also speaks of the supreme emptiness.
These three sutras and other places, with such characteristics, have already been spoken by the World-Honored One. They are also this.
If one correctly understands dependent origination, one understands emptiness.
If one does not understand dependent origination, one also does not understand emptiness.
As for the dependent origination explained above, if one correctly understands it, one's understanding is not different.
What else does one understand?
It means understanding emptiness.
If one does not understand dependent origination, one also does not understand emptiness. If one does not understand this dependent origination, one also cannot penetrate that emptiness.
One should understand it thus.
If one gives rise to pride towards emptiness, one will not be disgusted with the aggregates.

If one has the view of non-existence, one will be confused about the meaning of dependent origination.ğŸ”½If one gives rise to pride towards emptiness, one will not be disgusted with the five aggregates.
If one gives rise to pride towards emptiness, one will not be disgusted with the five aggregates.

If one is deluded about the meaning of dependent origination due to not seeing it, then among the four views, one will take up any one of them: the view of annihilation, the view of permanence, the view of being created by a supreme being, or the view of being created by one's own past actions.
Because one is not deluded about dependent origination, one is free from arrogance and knows emptiness.
And because one is disgusted with the aggregates of experience, one is not deluded about the combination of karma and its results.

Because one is not deluded about dependent origination, one is free from arrogance and knows emptiness. If one has no deluded mind regarding the various dependent originations explained above, and if one is able to be free from arrogance regarding the grasping of I and mine, then one will be able to enter emptiness in accordance with the Dharma.

And because one is disgusted with the aggregates of experience, one is not deluded about the combination of karma and its results. Because the aggregates of experience include the grasping of I and mine, one will revolve through the world without rest;
but because one gives rise to disgust and detachment towards those aggregates of experience, one will have no inversion or delusion regarding the continuity of karma and its results.
He asked again:
What does this mean?
Karma creates conditions for continuation of birth, but it is not without conditions.
In emptiness, there are conditions for this, the equipment of karmic retribution and enjoyment.

As for Karma creates conditions for continuation of birth, but it is not without conditions, the defilements and karma are as explained above. By means of such pure and impure karma, beings are impelled to continue in succession above and below.
If it were not for this karma, it would not create conditions.

If it were not so, then what has not yet been done would come, and what has already been done would be lost. This means that before the karma is done, its result comes, and what is lost means that after the karma is done, its result is lost.

As for In emptiness, there are conditions for this, the equipment of karmic retribution and enjoyment, if there is retribution and enjoyment due to such pure and impure karma, then its self-nature is empty.
Originally there is no self, but conditions are created to give rise to it. That self-nature is empty should also be understood.
The meaning of this is now briefly explained.
The twelve links are distinguished, as previously explained in dependent origination,
Among the three of afflictions, karma, and suffering, they are included as appropriate.
Ignorance is at the beginning, and old age and death are at the end. These are the distinctions of the twelve links of dependent origination, as previously explained.
Among them, three are afflictions, two are karma, and seven are suffering, all already included.
Three give rise to two, two give rise to seven,
And seven again give rise to three - the wheel of existence turns in this way.

The two kinds of formations produced by the three kinds of ignorance, craving, and grasping give rise to the seven links of consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, birth, and old age and death.
Among those seven links, as previously explained, they again give rise to the three kinds. Those three again give rise to two, and those two again give rise to seven.
Therefore, the two kinds turn in this way without interruption. This wheel of existence turns in this way.
In the world of causes, effects, and birth, there are no separate sentient beings,
Only empty dharmas give rise to empty dharmas.

As for In the world of causes, effects, and birth, there are no separate sentient beings, the five kinds called ignorance, volitional activity, craving, grasping, and existence are the causes, and the seven kinds called consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, birth, and old age and death are the effects. These pervade the world.
Whether it is a self, a sentient being, a life, a living being, a person, a human, or an agent, these are the main points, and one should know that they are all false discriminations.
How do they arise?

Only empty dharmas give rise to empty dharmas means that in the emptiness of self-nature, afflictions, karma, and fruits are provisionally named. There are only separate empty provisionally named afflictions, karma, and fruits that arise.
This is the meaning.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Afflictions arise due to conditions, karma also arises due to conditions,
Retribution also arises due to conditions, there is not a single one without conditions.
If there are afflictions, then there are various kinds of immeasurable karma, and various kinds of karmic fruits.
They all have common causes and common conditions, one should know this.
There is not a single place without causes and conditions.
Moreover, in order to clarify that meaning, I will now give another analogy.
Recitation, lamp, seal, mirror, sound, sunlight, seeds, vinegar,
Many continuations do not transcend to reach, the wise should observe those two.
Like recitation, there is the one who teaches recitation and the one who receives recitation. The one who teaches recitation does not reach the one who receives recitation.
Why is it so?
Because the one who teaches recitation still abides.
The one who teaches recitation also does not continue.
Why is it so?
Because it does not arise by itself.
Like a lamp successively arises, it is not that the first lamp transcends to reach, nor does the second arise without a cause.

The two of seal and image, the two of face and mirror, the two of sound and echo, the two of sun and fire, the two of seed and sprout, the two of vinegar and saliva, these all do not transcend, nor are they not born, nor are they born without a cause.
When the two kinds of five aggregates continue, it is not that the first aggregates transcend, yet the second aggregates are also not unborn and are not born without a cause.
The wise one, in this continuation of aggregates that does not transcend but gradually reaches, should contemplate correctly.
Moreover, the external and internal enjoyments both have ten kinds, all of which should be seen.

Among them, the ten kinds of external [characteristics] are: 1) impermanence, 2) non-annihilation, 3) non-transcendence, 4) no middle, 5) not their substance, 6) not different, 7) no creator, 8) not causeless, 9) momentariness, and 10) the continuity of similar effects.

Because the external seeds are completely extinguished, they are impermanent. Because the sprouts arise, they are not annihilated. After the seeds are completely extinguished, the sprouts originally did not exist but now exist, so they do not transcend.
The continuity is uninterrupted, because cause and effect are connected, so there is no middle.

Because the seeds and sprouts are different, they are not the same substance. Because they arise from that, they are not different. Because the causes and conditions are combined, there is no creator. Because the seeds are the cause, they are not causeless.
Because the seeds, sprouts, stems, branches, leaves, flowers, fruits, etc. are transmitted and produced, they are momentary.
Sweet, sour, salty, bitter, pungent, and astringent fruits transform and emerge according to the differences in causes, therefore similar fruits are bound within them.
The ten internal [elements] are: First, because the aggregates of sensation at the edge of death cease without remainder, they are impermanent;
Second, because the aggregates of sensation of the next life are obtained, they are not severed;

Third, after the aggregates of sensation at the edge of death cease without remainder, the aggregates of sensation of the next life, which were originally non-existent, now exist, thus they do not transcend;
Fourth, because the continuity of the aggregates of sensation is uninterrupted, and cause and effect are bound to each other, there is no middle;
Fifth, because the aggregates of sensation at the edge of death and the aggregates of sensation of the next life are different, they are not of the same substance;
Sixth, because they originate from that, they are not separate;
Seventh, because the causes and conditions are combined, there is no creator;
Eighth, because afflictions and karma are the causes, they are not without causes;
Ninth, the kalala, arbuda, peÅ›in, ghana, praÅ›ÄkhÄ, birth, infant, child, youth, and elder, etc., are transmitted and born in succession, so they are empty moment by moment;
Tenth, good and evil perfuming, following the differences in causes, the fruits turn out, so the fruits of the same kind are bound together.
There are also three verses:
Just as a lamp's flame turns and produces, so does the body of consciousness,
The beginning and end are also without aggregation.
Without arising, yet there is arising, destroying without attachment to characteristics,
Having arisen, yet there is no abiding, and this activity turns.
If one is able to observe and know emptiness in that dependent origination,
For them, I establish the teaching, that is also the middle way.
In this, ignorance, formations, craving, grasping, and becoming are the truth of accumulation.
Consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, birth, and old age and death, these are the truth of suffering.
The cessation of these twelve factors is the truth of cessation.
To be able to know the dependent origination as it truly is, this is the truth of the path.
Treatise on Dependent Origination
